DIV1.P: As it hath beene often presented with good allowance by her Maties Servants at the Phoenix in Drurie Lane.

LIST.HEAD: The Actors names.
LIST.ITEM: Calandrino, A merrie fellow servant to Giovanni.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE TRULY HO∣NORED, AND MY NOBLE Favourer, Sir ROBERT WISEMAN Knight, of Thorrells Hall in ESSEX.
DIV1.P:
AS I dare not be ungratefull for the many benefits you have heretofore conferr'd upon me, so I have just reason to feare that my attempting this way to make satisfaction (in some measure) for so due a debt, will further ingage me. How∣ever examples encourage me. The most able in my poore Quality have made use of Dedi∣cations in this Nature, to make the world take notice (as farre as in them lay) who, and what they were that gave supportment, and protection to their Studies, being more wil∣ling to publish the Dooer, then receive a be∣nefit in a corner. For my selfe, I wil freely, and
with a zealous thankfulnesse acknowledge, that for many yeares I had but faintly subsi∣sted, if I had not often tasted of your Bounty. But it is above my strength, and faculties, to celebrate to the desert, your noble inclination, (and that made actuall) to raise up, or to speak more properly, to rebuild the ruines of de∣molish'd Poesie. But that is a worke reser∣ved, and will be, no doubt, undertaken, and finished, by one that can to the life expresse it. Accept I beseech you the tender of my ser∣vice, and in the list of those you have obliged to you, contemne not the Name of

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your true and faithfull Honorer PHILIP MASSINGER.

DIV1.HEAD: On his great Duke of Florence; To Mr. PHILIP MASSINGER, my much esteemed friend.

LG.L: ENjoy thy Lawrell! 'tis a noble choice,
Not by the suffrages of voice
Procur'd; but by a conquest so atchiev'd
As that thou hast at full reliev'd
Almost neglected Poetrie; whose Bayes
(Sullid by childish thirst of praise)
Wither'd into a dulnesse of Despaire,
Had not thy later labour (heire
Vnto a former industrie) made knowne
This Work, which thou may'st call thine owne,
So rich in worth, that th'ignorant may grudge
To finde true vertue is become their Iudge.

DIV1.HEAD: To the deserving memory, of this worthy Worke, and the Author, Mr. PHILIP MASSINGER.

LG.L: ACtion gives many Poems right to live,
This Piece gave life to Action; and will give
For state, and language, in each change of Age,
To Time, delight; and honour to the stage.
Should late prescription faile which fames that Seat,
This Pen, might style The Duke of Florence Great.
Let many Write; Let much be Printed; read,
And censur'd; Toyes; no sooner-hatch't, then dead.
Here, without blush to Truth of commendation,
Is prov'd, how Art hath out-gone Imitation.

DIV1.HEAD: A COMICAL HISTORY OF THE GREAT DVKE OF FLORENCE.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: YOu bring your welcome with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: Sir, I finde it
In every circumstance.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Againe most welcome.
Yet give me leave to wish (and pray you excuse mee)
For I must use the freedome I was borne with)
The great Dukes pleasure had commanded you
To my poore house upon some other service,
Not this you are designde to; but his will
Must be obeyde, how ere it ravish from me
The happy conversation of one
As deere to me as the old Romans held
Their houshold Lars, whom they beleev'd had power
To blesse and guard their Families.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: 'Tis receiv'd so:
On my part Signior; nor can the Duke
But promise to himselfe as much as may
Be hop'd for from a Nephew. And t'were weaknesse
In any man to doubt, that Giovanni
Train'd up by your experience and care
In all those Arts peculiar, and proper
To future Greatnesse, of necessity
Must in his actions being growne a man
Make good the Princely education
Which Hee deriv'd from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: I have discharg'd,
To the utmost of my power, the trust the Duke
Committed to me, and with joy perceive
The seed of my endeavours was not sowen
Upon the barren sands, but fruitfull glebe,
Which yeelds a large encrease; my noble Charge,
By his sharp wit, and pregnant apprehension
Instructing those that teach him; making use
Not in a vulgar and pedantique forme
Of what's read to him, but 'tis streight digested
And truly made his owne. His grave discourse,
In one no more indebted unto yeares,
Amazes such as heare him; horsmanship
And skill to use his weapon are by practise
Familiar to him; as for Knowledge in
Musique, He needs it not, it being borne with him,
All that He speaks being with such grace deliver'd
That it makes perfit harmony.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: You describe
A wonder to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Sir, he is no lesse,
And that there may be nothing wanting that
May render him compleat, the sweetnesse of
His disposition so winnes on all
Appointed to attend him, that they are
Rivalls ev'n in the coursest office, who
Shall get praecedencie to doe him service.
Which they esteeme a greater happinesse
Then if they had beene fashion'd, and built up
To hold command o're others.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: And what place
Does he now blesse with his presence?

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: He is now
Running at the ring, at which he's excellent.
He does alott for every exercise
A severall houre, for Sloath the Nurse of vices
And rust of action, is a stranger to him.
But I feare I am tedious, let us passe
If you please to some other subject, though I cannot
Deliver him as he deserves.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: You have giv'n him
A noble character.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: And how I pray you
(For we that never looke beyond our villa's
Must be inquisitive) are State affaires
Carried in Court?

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: There's little alteration.
Some rise, and others fall; as it stands with
The pleasure of the Duke, their great disposer.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Does Lodovica Sanazarro hold
Waight, and grace with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: Every day new honours
Are showr'd upon him, and without the envie
Of such as are good men. Since all confesse
The service done our Master in his warres
'Gainst Pisa, and Sienna, may with justice
Claime what's conferr'd upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: 'Tis said nobly.
For Princes never more make knowne their wisdome
Then when they cherish goodnesse, where they finde it,
They being men, and not Gods, Contarino;
They can give wealth and titles, but no vertues;
That is without their power. When they advance
(Not out of judgement, but deceiving fancie)
An undeserving man, how ere set of
With all the trim of greatnesse, state, and power,
And of a creature ev'n growne terrible
To him from whom he tooke his Gyant forme,
This thing is still a Comet, no true starre;
And when the bounties feeding his false fire
Begin to faile, will of it selfe goe out,
And what was dreadfull, prooves ridiculous.
But in our Sanazarro 'tis not so.
He being pure and tride gold, and any stamp
Of grace to make him currant to the world
The Duke is pleas'd to give him, will adde honor
To the great bestower, for he though allow'd
Companion to his Master, still preserves
His Majestie in full lustre.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: Hee indeede
At no part does take from it, but becomes
A partner of his cares, and eases him,
With willing shoulders, of a burthen, which
Hee should alone sustaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Is Hee yet married?

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: No Signior, still a Batchelor, how e're
It is apparent, that the choycest Virgin
For beauty, bravery, and wealth in Florence,
Would with her Parents glad consent, be woon
(Were his affection, and intent but knowne)
To be at his devotion.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: So I think too.
But break we off. Here comes my Princely charge.
Make your approaches boldly, you will finde
A courteous entertainment.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Pray you forbeare
My hand, good Signior. 'Tis a ceremony
Not due to me. 'Tis fit we should embrace
With mutuall armes.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: It is a favour Sir
I grieve to be denide.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: You shall o're-come.
But tis your pleasure, not my pride that grants it.
Nay pray you Guardian, and good Sir, put on:
How ill it shewes to have that reverend head
Be uncover'd to a Boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Your Excellence
Must give me liberty to observe the distance
And duty that l'owe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Owe me duty?
I doe professe, and when I'doe denie it
Good fortune leave me; You have beene to me
A second Father, and may justly challenge
(For trayning up my youth in Arts, and Armes)
As much respect, and service, as was due
To him that gave me life. And did you know Sir
Or will beleeve from me, how many sleepes
Good Charomonte hath broken in his care
To build me up a man, you must confesse
Chiron the Tutor to the great Achilles
Compar'd with him, deserves not to be nam'd.
And if my gracious Uncle the great Duke
Still holds me worthy his consideration,
Or findes in me ought worthy to be lov'd,
That little rivolet flow'd from this spring,
And so from me report him.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: Fame already
Hath fill'd his Highnesse eares with the true story
Of what you are, and how much better'd by him.
And 'tis his purpose to reward the travaile
Of this grave Sir with a magnificent hand.
For though his tendernesse hardly could consent
To have you one houre absent from his sight,
For full three yeares he did denie himselfe
The pleasure Hee tooke in you, that you, here
From this great Master might arrive unto
The Theory of those high mysteries
Which you by action must make plaine in Court.
'Tis therefore his request (and that from him
Your Excellence must grant a strict command)
That instantly (it being not five houres riding)
You should take horse, and visit him. These his letters
Will yeeld you farther reasons.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: To the Court!
Farewell the flower then of the Countries garland.
This is our Sunne, and when Hee's set, we must not
Expect or Spring, or Summer, but resolve
For a perpetuall Winter.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Pray you observe
The frequent changes in his face.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: As if
His much unwillingnesse to leave your house,
Contended with his duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Now he appeares
Collected and resolv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: It is the Duke!
The Duke upon whose favour, all my hopes
And fortunes doe depend. Nor must I check
At his commands for any private motives
That doe invite my stay here, though they are
Almost not to be master'd. My obedience
In my departing suddenly shall confirme
I am his Highnesse creature. Yet I hope
A little stay to take a solemne farewell
For all those ravishing pleasures I have tasted
In this my sweet retirement, from my Guardian,
And his incomparable daughter, cannot meete
An ill construction.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: I will answer that,
Use your owne will.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: I would speake to your Sir
In such a phrase as might expresse the thanks
My heart would gladly pay. But. —

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: I conceive you:
And something I would say, but I must doe it
In that dumb rhetorique, which you make use of;
For I doe wish you all. — I know not how
My toughnesse melts, and spite of my discretion
I must turne woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: What a sympathic
There is betweene em.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: Were I on the Rack
I could not shed a teare. But I am mad,
And ten to one shall hang my selfe for sorrow
Before I shift my shirt. But heare you Sir,
I'll separate you. When you are gone, what will
Become of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: Why thou shalt to Court with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: To see you worried?

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: Worried Calandrino?

SP.SPEAKER: Caland.
SP.L: Yes Sir. For bring this sweet face to the Court
There will be such a longing 'mong the Madames,
Who shall ingrosse it first, nay fight and scratch for't,
That if they be not stop'd, for entertainment
They'll kisse his lips off. Nay, if you'll soape so
And not be tempted to a farther danger,
These Succube are so sharp set, that you must
Give out you are an Eunuch.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: Have a better
Opinion of Court-Ladies, and take care
Of your owne stake.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: For my stake 'tis past caring,
I would not have a bird of uncleane feathers
Hansell his Limetwig, and so much for him.
There's something else that troubles me.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Caland.
SP.L: Why how to behave my self in Court, & tytely
I have beene told the very place transformes men,
And that not one of a thousand, that before
Liv'd honestly in the Country, on plaine Sallads,
But bring him thither, marke me that, and feed him
But a moneth or two with Custards and Court Cakebread,
And he turnes Knave immediately. I would be honest;
But I must follow the fashion, or die a beggar.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: And if I ever reach my hopes, beleeve it
We will share fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: This acknowledgement
Bindes me your debtor ever. Here comes one
In whose sad lookes you easily may reade
What her heart suffers, in that she is forc'd
To take her last leave of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: As I live
A beauty without parallel

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: Must you goo then
So suddenly?

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: There's no evasion, Lydia,
To gaine the least delay, though I would buy it
At any rate. Greatnesse with private men
Esteem'd a blessing, is to me a curse.
And we, whom for our high births, they conclude
The onely free men, are the onely slaves:
Happy the golden meane I had I beene borne
In a poore sordid Cottage; not nurs'd up
With expectation to command a Court:
I might, like such of your condition (Sweetest)
Have tooke a safe and middle course, and not
As I am now against my choyse compell'd
Or to lye groveling on the earth, or rais'd
So high upon the pinnacles of State,
That I must either keepe my height with danger,
Or fall with certaine ruine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: Your owne goodnesse
Will be your faithfull guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: O Lidia.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: So passionate!

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: For had I beene your equall
I might have seene and lik'd with mine own eyes,
And not as now with others; I might still,
And without observation, or envie,
As I have done, continued my delights
With you, that are alone in my esteeme
The abstract of Society; we might walke
In solitary Groves, or in choyce Gardens;
From the variety of curious flowers
Contemplate natures workmanship, and wonders.
And then for change, neare to the murmur of
Some bubling fountaine, I might heare you sing,
And from the well-tun'd accents of your tongue
In my imagination conceive
With what mellodious harmony a Quire
Of Angells sing above, their Makers praises.
And then with chast discourse, as we return'd,
Impe feathers to the broken wings of Time,
And all this I must part from.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: You forget
The hast impoi'd upon us.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: One word more
And then I come. And after this, when with
Continued innocence, of love, and service,
I had growne ripe for Hymenaeall joyes
Embracing you, but with a lawfull flame
I might have beene your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: Sir, I was
And ever am your servant, but it was,
And 'tis farre from me, in a thought to cherish
Such sawcie hopes: If I had beene the heire
Of all the Globes and Scepters mankind bowes to,
At my best you had deserv'd me; as I am
How e're unworthy, in my virgin zeale
I wish you as a partner of your bed,
A Princesse equall to you, such a one
That may make it the study of her life,
With all th'obedience of a wife to please you.
May you have happy issue, and I live
To be their humblest handmayde.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: I am dumb,
And can make no reply.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: Your Excellence
Will be benighted.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: This kisse bath'd in teares
May learne you what I should say.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: Give me leave
To wayt on you to your horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: And me to bring you
To the one halfe of your journey.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Your love puts
Your age to too much trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: I grow young
When most I serve you.

SP.SPEAKER: Conta.
SP.L: Sir, the Duke shal thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Alphonso.
SP.L: HIs Highnesse cannot take it ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Hippolito.
SP.L: However,
We with our duties shall expresse our care
For the safety of his Dukedome.

SP.SPEAKER: Hieronimo.
SP.L: And our loves
To his person. Here he comes. Present it boldly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: What needs this form? we are not grown so proud
As to disdaine familiar conference
With such as are to counsaile, and direct us.
This kinde of adoration shew'd not well
In the old Roman Emperors, who forgetting
That they were flesh & blood, would be styl'd gods,
In us to suffer it were worse. Pray you rise.
Still the old suit, with too much curiousnesse
You have too often search'd this wound, which yeelds
Security and rest, not trouble to me.
For here you grieve, that my firme resolution
Continues me a Widdower; and that
My want of issue to succeede me in
My government, when I am dead, may breed
Distraction in the State, and make the name
And family of the Medices, now admir'd,
Contemptible.

SP.SPEAKER: Hippolito.
SP.L: And with strong reasons Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Alphonso.
SP.L: For were you old and past hope to beget
The modell of your selfe; we should be silent.

SP.SPEAKER: Hieronimo.
SP.L: But being in your height and pride of yeeres
As you are now great Sir, and having too
In your possession the daughter of
The deceas'd Duke of Vrbin, and his heire,
Whose Guardian you are made, were you but pleas'd
To think her worthy of you, besides children
The Dukedome she brings with her for a dower,
Will yeeld a large encrease of strength and power
To those faire territories, which already
Acknowledge you their absolute Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: You presse us
VVith solid arguments we grant, and though
VVe stand not bound to yeeld account to any
VVhy we doe this or that (the full consent
Of our Subjects being included in our Will)
We out of our free bounties will deliver
The motives that divert us. You well know
That three yeeres since to our much griefe, we lost
Our Dutches, such a Dutches, that the world
In her whole course of life, yeelds not a Lady
That can with imitation deserve
To be her second: in her grave we buried
All thoughts of woman: let this satisfie
For any second marriage. Now whereas
You name the heire of Vrbin, as a Princesse
Of great revenues, 'tis confess'd she is so;
But for some causes private to our selfe,
We have dispos'd her otherwise. Yet despaire not,
For you ere long with joy shall understand,
That in our Princely care we have provided
One worthy to succeed us.

SP.SPEAKER: Hippolito.
SP.L: We submit,
And hold the counsailes of great Cozimo
Oraculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: My Sanazaro. Nay,
Forbeare all ceremony. You looke sprightly friend,
And promise in your cleare aspect some novell
That may delight us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: O Sir, I would not be
The Harbinger of ought that might distast you.
And therefore know (for 'twere a sinne to torture
Your Highnesse expectation) your Vice-Admirall
By my directions hath surpriz'd the Gallies
Appointed to transport the Asian tribute
Of the great Turke, a richer Prize was never
Brought into Florence.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Still my Nightingale,
That with sweet accents doest assure me, that
My Spring of happinesse comes fast upon me.
Embrace me boldly. I pronounce that wretch
An enemy to brave and thriving action,
That dares beleeve, but in a thought, we are
Too prodigall in our favours to this man,
Whose merits, though with him we should devide
Our Dukedome, still continuous his debtor.

SP.SPEAKER: Hippolito.
SP.L: 'Tis farre from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alphonso.
SP.L: We all applaud it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Nay, blush not Sanazarro, we are proud
Of what we build up in thee, nor can our
Election be disparag'd; since we have not
Receiv'd into our bosome and our grace
A glorious lazie Droane, growne fat with feeding
On others toyle, but an industrious Bee
That crops the sweet flowers of our enemies,
And every happy evening returnes
Loaden with wax and hony to our Hive.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: My best endevours never can discharge
The service I should pay.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Thou art too modest,
But we will study how to give, and when,
Before it be demanded. Giovanni!
My Nephew; let me eye thee better Boy.
In thee me thinks my Sister lives againe:
For her love I will be a Father to thee,
For thou art my adopted Sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Your Servant
And humblest Subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Thy hard travaile Nephew
Requires soft rest, and therefore we forbeare
For the present an account, how thou hast spent
Thy absent houres. See Signiors, see, our care
Without a second bed provides you of
A hopefull Prince. Carrie him to his Lodgings,
And for his farther honour Sanazarro
With the rest doe you attend him.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: All true pleasures
Circle your Highnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: As the rising Sunne
VVe doe receive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: May this never set,
SP.STAGE: Exeunt Giovanni, Sanazarro, Hieronimo, Alphonso, Lodovico, Cozimo.
SP.L: But shine upon you ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Contarino!

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: My gracious Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: What entertainment found you
From Carolo de Charamonte?

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: Free
And bountifull. He's ever like himselfe
Noble and hospitable.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: But did my Nephew
Depart thence willingly?

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: He obey'd your summons
As did become him. Yet it was apparent
But that he durst not crosse your will, he would
Have sojourn'd longer there, he ever finding
Variety of sweetest entertainment;
But there was something else, nor can I blame
His youth, though with some trouble he took leave
Of such a sweet companion.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Who was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: The daughter sir of Signior Carolo,
Faire Lidia, a virgin at all parts,
But in her birth and fortunes, equall to him.
The rarest beauties Italy can make boast of,
Are but meere shadowes to her, she the substance
Of all perfection. And what encreases
The wonder Sir, Her bodies matchlesse forme
Is better'd by the purenesse of her soule.
Such sweet discourse, such ravishing behaviour;
Such charming language, such inchanting manners,
With a simplicity that shames all Courtship,
Flow hourely from her, that I doe beleeve
Had Circe, or Calipso her sweet graces,
Wandring Vlisses never had remembred
Penelope, or Ithaca.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Be not rap'd so.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: Your Excellence would be so had you seen her

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Take up. Take up. But did your observation
Note any passage of affection
Betweene her and my Nephew?

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: How it should
Be otherwise betweene 'em, is beyond
My best imagination. Cupids arrowes
Were uselesse there, for of necessity
Their yeeres and dispositions doe accord so
They must wound one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Umh! Thou art
My Secretary Contarino, and more skill'd
In politique designes of State, then in
Thy iudgement of a beauty; give me leave
In this to doubt it. Here. Goe to my Cabinet,
You shal find there Letters newly receiv'd touching the state of Vrbin.
Pray you with care peruse them, leave the search
Of this to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: I doe obey in all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Lydia! A Diamond so long conceal'd,
And never worne in Court! of such sweet feature?
And he on whom I fixe my Dukedomes hopes,
Made Captive to it! Vmh! 'tis somewhat strange,
Our eyes are every where, and we will make
A strict enquiry, Sanazarro!

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Is my Nephew at his rest?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: I saw him in bed Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: 'Tis well, and does the Princes Fiorinda
(Nay, doe not blush, she is rich Vrbins heire)
Continue constant in her favours to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Dread sir, she may dispense thē as she pleases,
But I looke up to her as on a Princesse
I dare not be ambitious of, and hope
Her prodigall graces shall not render me
Offended to your Highnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Not a scruple.
He whom I favour as I doe my friend,
May take all lawfull graces that become him.
But touching this hereafter; I have now
(And though perhaps it may appear or trifle)
Serious imployment for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: I stand ready
For any act you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: I know it friend,
Have you ne're heard of Lidia the daughter
Of Carolo Charamonte?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: Him I know sir
For a noble Gentleman, and my worthy friend,
But never heard of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: She is deliver'd
And feelingly to us by Contarino
For a master-peece in nature, I would have you
Ride suddenly thither to behold this wonder:
But not as sent by us, that's our first caution:
The second is, and carefully observe it,
That though you are a Batchelor, & endow'd with
All those perfections that may take a virgin,
On forfeit of our favour doe not tempt her.
It may be her faire graces doe concerne us.
Pretend what businesse you think fit, to gaine
Accesse into her Fathers house, and there
Make full discovery of her, and returne me
A true relation, I have some ends in it
With which we will acquaint you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: This is Sir
An easie taske.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Yet one that must exact
Your secrecie, and diligence. Let not
Your stay be long.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: It shall not sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Farewell,
And be, as you would keepe our favour, carefull.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: HOw does this dressing show?

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: 'Tis of itselfe
Curious and rare: but borrowing ornament
As it does from your Grace, that daine sto weare it,
Incomparable.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: Thou flatter'st me.

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: I cannot,
Your Excellence is above it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: Were we lesse perfect,
Yet being as we are an absolute Princesse,
We of necessity must be chast, wise, faire,
By our prerogative. Yet all these faile
To move where I would have them. How receiv'd
Count Sanazarro the rich Scarfe I sent him
For his last Visit?

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: With much reverence,
I dare not say affection. He express'd
More ceremonie in his humble thanks
Then feeling of the favour; and appear'd
Wilfully ignorant in my opinion
Of what it did invite him to.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: No matter,
He's blinde with too much light. Have you not heard
Of any private Mistresse he's ingag'd to?

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: Not any, and this does amaze me Madame,
That he, a Souldier, one that drinks rich wines,
Feedes high, and promises as much as Venus
Could wish to finde from Mars, should in his manners
Be so averse to women.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: Troth I know not,
He's man enough, and if he has a haunt,
He preyes farre off like a subtill Fox.

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: And that way
I doe suspect him. For I learnt last night
(When the great Duke went to rest) attended by
One private follower, he tooke horse, but whither
He's rid, or to what end I cannot guesse at,
But I will finde it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: Doe faithfull servant,
We would not be abus'd. Who have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: How the foole stares?

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: And lookes as if he were
Conning his neck-verse.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: If I now proove perfect
In my A. B. C. of Courtship, Calandrino
Is made for ever, I am sent; let me see,
On a how doe you, as they call't.

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: What would'st thou say?

SP.SPEAKER: Calan.
SP.L: Let me see thy notes. These are her lodgings. Well.

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: Art thou an Asse?

SP.SPEAKER: Caland.
SP.L: Peace, thou art a Court wagtaile
SP.STAGE: Calandrino still looking on his instructions. Fi. o. rin. da.
SP.L: To interrupt me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: He has giv'n it you.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: And then say to th'illustrious
I have it. VVhich is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: VVhy this; Fopdoodle.

SP.SPEAKER: Calan.
SP.L: Leave chattering Bulfinch: you would put me out,
But 't will not doe. Then after you have made
Your three obeysances to her, kneele and kisse
The skirt of Gowne. I am glad it is no worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: And why so sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: Because I was afraid
That after the Italian garbe I should
Have kiss'd her backward.

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: This is sport unlook'd for.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: Are you the Princesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: Yes sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: Then stand faire
(For I am cholerick) and doe not nip
A hopefull blosome. Out againe. Three low
Obeysances.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: I am ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: I come on then.

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: With much formality.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: Umph. One. two. three.
Thus farre I am right. Now for the last. O rare!
Shee is perfum'd all over! Sure great women
Instead of little dogges are priviledg'd
To carrie Musk Cats.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: Now the ceremony
Is pass'd, what is the substance?

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: I'll peruse
My instructions, and then tell you: Her skirt kiss'd,
Informe her Highnesse, that your Lord,

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: Who's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: Prince Giovanni, who entreates your Grace,
That he with your good favour may have leave
To present his service to you. I think I have nick'd it
For a Courtier of the first forme.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: To my wonder:
Returne unto the Prince: but he prevents
My answer. Calaminta take him off,
And for the neate delivery of his message
Give him ten Duccats, such rare parts as yours
Are to be cherish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: We will share. I know
It is the custome of the Court, when ten
Are promis'd, five is faire. Fie, fie, the Princesse
Shall never know it, so you dispatch me quickly,
And bid me not come to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Calaminta.
SP.L: Very good sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Pray you friend
Informe the Duke I am putting into act
What he commanded.

SP.SPEAKER: Gentleman.
SP.L: I am proud to be imploy'd sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: Madam, that without warrant I presume
To trench upon your Privacies, may argue
Rudenesse of manners. But the free accesse
Your Princely courtesie vouchsafes to all
That come to pay their services, gives me hope
To finde a gracious pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: If you please, not
To make that an offence in your construction,
Which I receive as a large favour from you,
There needes not this Apologie.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: You continue
As you were ever, the greatest Mistresse of
Faire entertainment.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: You are Sir the Master,
And in the Country have learnt to out-doe
All that in Court is practis'd. But why should we
Talke at such distance? You are welcome sir.
We have beene more familiar, and since
You wil impose the Province, you should governe,
Of boldnesse on me, give me leave to say
You are too punctuall. Sit sir, and discourse
As we were us'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Your Excellence knowes so well
How to command, that I can never erre
When I obey you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: Nay, no more of this.
You shall o'recome; no more I pray you sir.
And what delights, Pray you be liberall
In your relation, hath the Country life
Afforded you?

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: All pleasures gracious Madame,
But the happinesse to converse with your sweet vertues.
I had a grave Instructer, and my houres
Design'd to serious Studies yeelded me
Pleasure with profit in the knowledge of
What before I was ignorant in. The Signior
Carolode Charomonte being skilfull
To guide me through the labyrinth of wilde passions,
That labour'd to imprison my free soule
A slave to vitious Sloath.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: You speake him well.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: But short of his deserts. Then for the time
Of recreation I was allow'd
(Against the forme follow'd by jealous Parents
In Italy) full liberty to pertake
His daughters sweet society. She's a virgin
Happy in all endowments, which a Poet
Could fancie in his Mistresse: being her selfe
A Schoole of goodnesse, where chast Mayds may learne
(Without the aydes of forraigne Principles)
By the example of her life and purenesse
To be as she is, excellent. I but give you
A briefe Epitome of her vertues, which
Dilated on at large, and to their merit,
Would make an ample Story.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: Your whole age
So spent with such a Father, and a Daughter,
Could not be tedious to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: True great Princesse:
And now since you have pleas'd to grant the hearing
Of my times expence in the Country, give me leave
To entreate the favour, to be made acquainted
What service, or what objects in the Court
Have in your Excellence acceptance, prov'd
Most gracious to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: I'll meete your demand,
And make a plaine discovery. The Dukes care
For my estate and person holds the first
And choycest place. Then the respect the Courtiers
Pay gladly to me, not to be contemn'd.
But that which rais'd in me the most delight
(For I am a friend to valour) was to heare
The noble actions truly reported
Of the brave Count Sanazarro. I professe
When it hath beene, and fervently deliver'd.
How boldly in the horror of a fight
Cover'd with fire and smoake, and as if nature
Had lent him wings, like lightning he hath falne
Upon the Turkish Gallies, I have heard it
With a kinde of pleasure, which hath whisper'd to me
This Worthy must be cherish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: 'T was a bounty
You never can repent.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: I glory in it.
And when he did returne (but still with conquest)
His Armour off not young Antinous
Appear'd more Courtly; all the Graces that
Render a mans Society deere to Ladies,
Like Pages wayting on him, and it does
VVorke strangely on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: To divert your thoughts
Though they are fixt upon a noble subject,
I am a suitor to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: You will aske
I doe presume, what I may grant, and then
It must not be deni'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: It is a favour
For which I hope your Excellence will thank me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: Nay, without circumstance.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: That you would please
To take occasion to move the Duke,
That you with his allowance may command
This matchlesse virgin Lidia (of whom
I cannot speake too much) to waite upon you.
She's such a one, upon the forfeit of
Your good opinion of me, that will not
Be a blemish to your trayne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: 'Tis ranke! He loves her;
But I will fit him with a suit. I pause not
As if it bred or doubt or scruple in me
To doe what you desire, for I'll effect it,
And make use of a faire and fit occasion.
Yet in returne I aske a boone of you,
And hope to finde you, in your grant to me
As I have beene to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Command me Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: 'Tis neere allyde to yours. That you would be
A Suitor to the Duke, not to expose
(After so many trialls of his faith)
The noble Sanazarro to all dangers,
As if he were a wall to stand the furie
Of a perpetuall batterie: but now
To grant him after his long labours, rest
And liberty to live in Court, his Armes
And his victorious sword and shield hung up
For monuments.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: Umph. I'll embrace faire Princea
The soonest oportunity. The Duke!

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Nay, blush not; we smile on your privacie,
And come not to disturbe you. You are equalls,
And without prejudice to eithers Honors.
May make a mutuall change of love and Courtship,
Till you are made one, and with holy rites,
And we give suffrage to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: You are gracious.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: To our selfe in this. But now break off. Too much
Taken at once of the most curious viands
Dulls the sharp edge of appetite. We are now
For other sports, in which our pleasure is
That you shall keepe us company.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: We attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bernardo.
SP.L: IS my Lord stirring?

SP.SPEAKER: Caponi.
SP.L: No; He's fast.

SP.SPEAKER: Petruchio.
SP.L: Let us take then
Our morning draught. Such as eate store of Beefe,
Mutton, and Capons, may preserve their healths
With that thin composition call'd small Beere,
As 'tis said they doe in England. But Italians
That think when they have sup'd upon an Olive,
A Root, or bunch of Raysins, 'tis a Feast,
Must kill those cludities, rising from cold hearbs,
With hot and lusty wines.

SP.SPEAKER: Caponi.
SP.L: A happinesse
Those Tramontaines ne're casted.

SP.SPEAKER: Bernardo.
SP.L: Have they not
Store of wine there?

SP.SPEAKER: Caponi.
SP.L: Yes, and drink more in two houres
Then the Dutchmen, or the Dane in foure and twenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Petru.
SP.L: But what is't? French trash, made of rotten grapes
And dregs, and lees of Spaine, with Welch Metheglyn,
A drench to kill a horse, but this pure Nectar
Being proper to our climate, is too fine
To brook the roughnesse of the Sea. The spirit
Of this begets in us quick apprehensions
And active executions, whereas their
Grosse feeding makes their understanding like it.
They can fight, and that's their all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Security
Dwells about this house I think, the gate's wide open,
And not a servant stirring. See the horses
Set up, and cloath'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.L: I shall Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: I'll make bold
To presse a little further.

SP.SPEAKER: Bernardo.
SP.L: Who is this,
Count Sanazarro?

SP.SPEAKER: Petruchio.
SP.L: Yes, I know him. Quickly
Remove the Flaggon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: A good day to you friends.
Nay, doe not conceale your Physick, I approve it,
And if you please will be a Patient with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Petruchio.
SP.L: My noble Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: A health to yours. Well done,
I see you love your selves. And I commend you
'Tis the best wisedome.

SP.SPEAKER: Petruchio.
SP.L: May it please your Honour
To walk a turne in the Gallery, I ll acquaint
My Lord with your being here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Tell him I come
For a Visit onely. 'Tis a hansome pile this.

SP.SPEAKER: Caponi.
SP.L: Why here is a brave fellow, and a right one,
Nor wealth, nor greatnesse makes him proud.

SP.SPEAKER: Bernar.
SP.L: There are too few of them, for most of our new Courtlers
(Whose Fathers were familiar with the prices
Of oyle, and corne, with when and to where to vent 'em)
And left their heires rich from their knowledge that way)
Like gourds shot up in a night, disclaine to speake
But to cloath of Tissue.
SP.STAGE: Ent. Car. Charom. in a night-Gown. Petruchio following.

SP.SPEAKER: Carol.
SP.L: Stand you prating, knaves,
When such a guest is under my roofe? See all
The roomes perfum'd. This is the man that carries
The sway, and swinge of the Court; and I had rather
Preserve him mine with honest offices, then. —
But I'll make no comparisons. Bid my daughter
Trim her selfe up to the height, I know this Courtier
Must have a smack at her, and perhaps by his place
Expects to wriggle further. If he does
I shall deceive his hopes, for I'll not taint
My Honour for the Dukedome. Which way went he?

SP.SPEAKER: Caponi.
SP.L: To the round Gallerie.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: I will entertaine him.
As fits his worth, and quality, but no farther.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: I Cannot apprehend, yet I have argu'd
All wayes I can imagine, for what reasons
The great Duke does imploy me hither, and
What does encrease the miracle, I must render
A strict and true account, at my returne
Of Lidia this Lords daughter, and describe
In what she's excellent, and where defective.
'Tis a hard task; he that will undergoe
To make a judgement of a womans beauty,
And see through all her plaistrings, and paintings,
Had neede of Linceus eyes, and with more ease
May looke like him through nine mud walls, then make
A true discovery of her. But th'intents
And secrets of my Princes heart must be
Serv'd and not search'd into.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Most noble Sir
Excuse my age subject to ease, and Sloath,
That with no greaver speed I have presented
My service with your welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro
SP.L: 'Tis more fit
That I should aske your pardon for disturbing
Your restat this unseasonable houre.
But my occasions carrying me so neere
Your hospitable house, my stay being short to;
Your goodnesse, and the name of friend, which you
Are pleas'd to grace me with, gave me assurance
A Visit would not offend.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Offend my Lord?
I feele my selfe much younger for the favour.
How is it with our gracious Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: He Sir
Holds still his wonted Greatnesse, and confesses
Himselfe your debtor, for your love, and care
To the Prince Giovanni, and had sent
Particular thanks by me, had his Grace knowne,
The quick dispatch of what I was design'd to
Would have licenc'd me to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: I am rich
In his acknowledgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Sir, I have heard
Your happinesse in a daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Sits the winde there?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Fame gives her out for a rare master-peece.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: 'Tis a plaine Village Girle Sir, but obedient,
That's her best beauty Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Let my desire
To see her, finde a faire construction from you,
I bring no loose thought with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: You are that way
My Lord free from suspition. Her owne manners
(Without an imposition from me)
I hope will prompt her to it. As she is
She's come to make a tender of that service
Which she stands bound to pay.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: With your faire leave
I make bold to salute you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: Sir, I, you have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Petronella.
SP.L: I am her Gentlewoman, wil he not kisse me to?
This is course ifaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: How he falls off!

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: My Lord, though silence best becomes a Mayde,
And to be curious to know but what concernes my selfe, and with becomming distance,
May argue me of boldnesse, I must borrow
So much of modesty as to enquire Prince Giovannies health?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: Hee cannot want, what you are pleas'd to wish him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: Would 'twere so,
And then there is no blessing that can make
A hopefull and a noble Prince compleat,
But should fall on him. O, he was our North star,
The light and pleasure of our eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Where am I?
I feele my selfe another thing! Can charmes
Be writ on such pure Rubies? Her lips melt
Assoone as touch'd! not those smooth gales that glide
O're happy Arabie, or rich Sabaea,
Creating in their passage gummes and spices,
Can serve for a weake simile to expresse
The sweetnesse of her breath. Such a brave stature
Homer bestow'd on Pallas, every limbe
Proportion'd to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: This is strange; my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanaza.
SP.L: I crave your pardon, and yours, matchlesse Mayd,
For such I must report you.

SP.SPEAKER: Petronella.
SP.L: There's no notice
Taken all this while of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: And I must adde
If your discourse and reason parallel
The rarenesse of your more then humane forme,
You are a wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Pray you my Lord make triall:
She can speak I can assure you, and that my presence
May not take from her freedome, I will leave you.
For know my Lord, my confidence dares trust her
Where, and with whom she pleases. If he be
Taken the right way with her, I cannot fancie
A better match; and for false play I know
The tricks, and can discerne them. Petronella!

SP.SPEAKER: Petronella.
SP.L: Yes my good Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: I have imployment for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: What's your will Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Madame, you are so large a theame to treat of,
And every Grace about you offers to me
Such copiousnesse of language, that I stand
Doubtfull which first to touch at. If I erre,
As in my choyce I may, let me entreat you
Before I doe offend, to signe my pardon,
Let this the Emblem of your innocence
Give me assurance.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: My hand joyn'd to yours
Without this superstition confirmes it.
Nor neede I feare you will dwell long upon me,
The barrennesse of the subject yeelding nothing
That Rhetorick with all her tropes and figures
Can amplifie. Yet since you are resolv'd
To prove your selfe a Courtier in my praise,
As I am a woman (and you men affirme
Our sex loves to be flatter'd) I'll endure it.
Now when you please begin.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Such Laedas paps were,
Down pillowes styl'd by Jove. And their pure whitenesse
Shames the Swans Down, or snow. No heat of lust
Swells up her Azure veines. And yet I feele
That this chast Ice but touch'd fans fire in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: You neede not noble Sir be thus transported,
Or trouble your invention to expresse
Your thought of me: the plainest phrase and language
That you can use, will be too high a straine
For such an humble Theme.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: If the great Duke
Made this his end to try my constant temper,
Though I am vanquish'd, 'tis his fault, not mine.
For I am flesh and blood, and have affections
Like other men. Who can behold the Temples,
Or holy Altars, but the Objects worke
Devotion in him? And I may as well
Walke over burning iron with bare feet
And be unscorch'd, as looke upon this beauty
Without desire, and that desire pursu'd to,
Till it be quench'd with the enjoying those
Delights, which to atchieve danger is nothing,
And loyalty but a word.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: I ne're was proud,
Nor can finde I am guilty of a thought
Deserving this neglect, and strangenesse from you,
Nor am I amorous.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Suppose his Greatnesse
Loves her himselfe, why makes he choyce of me
To be his agent? it is tyrannie
To call one pinch'd with hunger to a feast,
And at that instant cruelly deny him
To taste of what he sees. Alleageance
Tempted too farre, is like the triall of
A good sword on an Anvill; as that often
Flies in peeces without service to the owner;
So trust enforc'd too farre prooves treachery,
And is too late repented.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: Pray you Sir,
Or licence me to leave you, or deliver
The reasons which invite you to command
My tedious wayting on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: As I live
I know not what to think on't. Is't his pride,
Or his simplicity?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Whither have my thoughts
Carried me from my selfe? in this my dulnesse,
I have lost an oportunity.
SP.STAGE: He turnes to her. She falls off.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: 'Tis true,
I was not bred in Court, not live a starre there,
Nor shine in rich embroderies, and pearle,
As they that are the Mistresses of great fortunes,
Are every day adorn'd with.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazaro.
SP.L: Will you vouchsafe
Your eare sweet Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: Yet I may be bold
For my integrity, and fame, to ranke
With such as are more glorious. Though I never
Did injurie, yet I am sensible
When I am contemn'd, and scorn'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Will you please to heare me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: O the difference of natures. Giovanni,
A Prince in expectation, when he liv'd here,
Stole courtesie from heaven, and would not to
The meanest servant in my Fathers house
Have kept such distance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Pray you doe not think me
Unworthy of your eare, it was your beauty
That turn'd me statue, I can speake, faire Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: And I can heare. The harshnesse of your Courtship
Cannot corrupt my curtesie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Will you heare me
If I speake of love?

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: Provided you be modest,
I were uncivill else.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: They are come to parlee,
I must observe this neerer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: You are a rare one,
And such (but that my hast commands me hence)
I could converse with ever. Will you grace me
VVith leave to visit you againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: So you
At your returne to Court, doe me the favour
To make a tender of my humble service
To the Prince Giovanni.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Ever touching
Upon that string? And will you give me hope
Of future happinesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: That, as I shall finde you.
The Fort that's yeelded at the first assault,
Is hardly worth the taking.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: O, they are at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: She is a Magazine of all perfection,
And 'tis death to part from her, yet I must,
A parting kisse faire Maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: That custome grants you.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: A homely breakfast does attend your Lordship.
Such as the place affords.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: No, I have feasted
Already here, my thanks, and so I leave you.
I will see you againe. Till this unhappy houre
I was never lost, and what to doe or say
I have not yet determin'd,

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Gone so abruptly?
'Tis very strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: Under your favour Sir,
His comming hither was to little purpose
For any thing I heard from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Take heede Lidia!
I doe advise you with a Fathers love,
And tendernesse of your honour: as I would not
Have you course and harsh in giving entertainment,
So by no meanes be credulous. For great men
Till they have gain'd their ends are Giants in
Their promises, but those obtain'd, weake Pigmies
In their performance. And it is a maxime
Alow'd among them, so they may deceive
They may sweare any thing; for the Queen of love
As they hold constantly, does never punish,
But smile at Lovers perjuries. Yet be wise too,
And when you are su'd to in a noble way,
Be neither nice, nor scrupulous.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: All you speake Sir
I heare as Oracles, nor will digresse
From your directions.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: So shall you keepe
Your fame untainted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: As I would my life Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanaz.
SP.L: LEave the horses with my Groomes; but be you carefull
With your best diligence, and speed to finde out
The Prince, and humbly in my name entreat him
I may exchange some private conference with him
Before the great Duke know of my arrivall.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.L: I hast my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Here I'll attend his comming,
And see you keepe your selfe as much as may be
Conceal'd from all men else.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.L: To serve your Lordship
I wish I were invisible.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: I am driven
Into a desperate streight, and cannot steere
A middle course; and of the two extreames
Which I must make election of, I know not
Which is more full of horror. Never servant
Stood more ingag'd to a magnificent Master
Then I to Cozimo. And all those honors
And glories by his Grace conferr'd upon me,
Or by my prosperous services deserv'd,
If now I should deceive his trust, and make
A shipwrack of my loyalty, are ruin'd.
And on the other side, if I discover
Lidias divine perfections, all my hopes
In her are sunke, never to be boy'd up:
For 'tis impossible, but assoone as seene
She must with adoration be su'd to.
A Hermit at his beades, but looking on her,
Or the cold Cinique, whom Corinthian Lais,
Not mov'd with her lusts blandishments, call'd a stone,
At this object would take fire. Nor is the Duke
Such an Hippolitus, but that this Phaedra
But seene, must force him to forsake the Groves
And Dians Huntmanship, proud to serve under
Venus soft Ensignes. No, there is no way
For me to hope fruition of my ends,
But to conceale her beauties; and how that
May be effected, is as hard a taske
As with a vayle to cover the Sunnes beames,
Or comfortable light. Three yeares the Prince
Liv'd in her company, and Contarino
The Secretary, hath possess'd the Duke
What a rare peece she is. But he's my creature,
And may with ease be frighted to denie
What he hath said. And if my long experience
With some strong reasons I have thought upon,
Cannot o're-reach a youth, my practise yeelds me
But little profit.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: You are well return'd Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanaz.
SP.L: Leave us. When that your Grace shall know the motives
That forc'd me to invite you to this trouble,
You will excuse my manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Sir, there needs not
This circumstance betweene us. You are ever
My noble friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: You shall have further cause
To assure you of my faith and zeale to serve you.
And when I have committed to your trust
(Presuming still on your retentive silence)
A secret of no lesse importance, then
My honor, nay my head, it will confirme
What value you hold with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Pray you beleeve Sir
What you deliver to me, shall be lock'd up
In a strong Cabinet; of which you your selfe
Shall keepe the key. For here I pawne my Honor
(Which is the best security I can give yet)
It shall not be discover'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: This assurance
Is more then I with modesty could demand
From such a paymaster, but I must be suddaine,
And therefore to the purpose. Can your Excellence
In your imagination conceive
On what designe, or whither the Dukes will
Commanded me hence last night?

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: No I assure you,
And it had beene a rudenesse to enquire
Of that I was not call'd to.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Grant me hearing,
And I will make you truly understand,
It onely did concerne you.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Me my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: You in your present state, and future fortunes,
For both lye at the stake?

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: You much amaze me.
Pray you resolve this riddle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: You know the Duke,
If he die issue-lesse (as yet he is)
Determines you his Heire.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: It hath pleas'd his Highnesse
Oft to professe so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: But say, he should
Be woone to prove a second wife, on whom
He may beget a sonne, how in a moment
Will all those glorious expectations, which
Render you reverenc'd and remarkable,
Be in a moment blasted, how e're you are
His much lov'd sisters sonne?

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: I must beare it
With patience, and in me it is a duty
That I was borne with: and 'twere much unfit
For the receiver of a benefit
To offer for his owne ends, to prescribe
Lawes to the givers pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Sweetly answer'd,
And like your noble selfe. This your rare temper
So winnes upon me, that I would not live
(If that by honest Arts I can prevent it)
To see your hopes made frustrate. And but think
How you shall be transform'd from what you are,
Should this (as heaven avert it) ever happen,
It must disturbe your peace. For whereas now,
Being as you are receiv'd for the Heire apparant,
You are no sooner seene, but wondredat;
The Signiors making it a businesse to
Enquire how you have slep'd; and as you walke
The streetes of Florence, the glad multitude
In throngs presse but to see you, and with joy
The Father, pointing with his finger, tells
His sonne, This is the Prince, the hopefull Prince,
That must hereafter rule, and you obey him.
Great Ladies begge your picture, and make love
To that, despairing to enjoy the substance.
And but the last night, when't was onely rumor'd
That you were come to Court (as if you had
By Sea past hither from another world)
What generall showts, and acclamations follow'd,
The bells rung lowd, the boonfires blaz'd, and such
As lov'd not wine, carrow sing to your health,
Were drunk, and blush'd not at it. And is this
A happinesse to part with?

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: I allow these
As flourishes of Fortune, with which Princes
Are often sooth'd, but never yet esteem'd 'em
For reall blessings.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Yet all these were pay'd
To what you may be, not to what you are,
For if the great Duke but shew to his servants
A sonne of his owne, you shall like one obscure
Passe unregarded.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: I confesse, command
Is not to be contemn'd, and if my Fate
Appoint me to it, as I may I'll beare it
With willing shoulders. But my Lord as yet
You have tolde me of a danger comming towards me,
But have not nam'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: That is soone deliver'd;
Great Cozimo your Uncle, as I more
Then guesse, for 'tis no frivolous circumstance
That does perswade my judgement to beleeve it,
Purposes to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Married, Sir?
With whom, and on what termes, pray you instruct me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: With the faire Lidia.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Lidia?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: The daughter
Of Signior Charomonte.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Pardon me
Though I appeare incredulons, for on
My knowledge he ne're saw her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: That is granted;
But Contarino hath so sung her praises,
And giv'n her out for such a master-peece,
That he's transported with it Sir. And love
Steales sometimes through the care into the heart
As well as by the eye. The Duke no sooner
Heard her describ'd, but I was sent in post
To see her, and returne my judgement of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: And what's your censure?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: 'Tis a pretie creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: She's very faire.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: Yes, yes, I have seene worse faces.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Her limbs are neatly form'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: She hath a waste
Indeede siz'd to loves wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: A delicate hand too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: Then for a legge and foote.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: And there I leave you,
For I presum'd no further.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: As she is Sir
I know she wants no gracious part that may
Allure the Duke, and if he onely see her
She is his owne. He will not be deni'd,
And then you are lost. Yet if you'll second me
(As you haue reason, for it most concernes you)
I can prevent all yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: I would you could
A noble way.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: I will cry downe her beauties;
Especially the beauties of her minde,
As much as Contarino hath advanc'd 'em,
And this I hope, will breed forgetfulnesse,
And kill affection in him: but you must
Joyne with me in my report, if you be question'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: I never told a lye yet, and I hold it
In some degree blasphemous to dispraise
What's worthy admiration. Yet for once
I will dispraise a little, and not varie
From your relation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: Be constant in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.L: My Lord, the Duke hath seen your man, & wonders
You come not to him. See if his desire
To have cōference with you hath not brought
Him hither in his owne person.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: They are comely coursers,
And promise swiftnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: They are of my knowledge
Of the best race in Naples.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: You are Nephew,
As I heare, an excellent horseman, and we like it.
'Tis a faire grace in a Prince. Pray you make triall
Of their strength and speed, and if you think them fit
For your imployment, with a liberall hand
Reward the Gentleman, that did present 'em
From the Viceroy of Naples.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: I will use
My best endeyour Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Wayte on my Nephew.
Nay stay you Contarino, be within call,
It may be we shal use you. You have rode hard Sir,
And we thank you for it. Every minute seemes
Irksome, and tedious to us; till you have
Made your discovery. Say friend, have you seene
This Phaenix of our age?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: I have seene a Mayde Sir,
But if that I have judgement, no such wonder
As she was deliver'd to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: This is strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: But certaine truth, it may be she was look'd on
With admiration in the Country Sir,
But if compar'd with many in your Court,
She would appeare but ordinary.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Contarino
Reports her otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: Such as ne're saw Swannes,
May think Crowes beautifull.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: How is her behaviour?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: 'Tis like the place she lives in.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: How her wit,
Discourse, and entertainment?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: Very course,
I would not willingly say poore, and rude,
But had she all the beauties of faire women,
The dulnesse of her soule would fright me from her.

SP.SPEAKER: Coz.
SP.L: You are curious Sir, I know not what to think on't.
Contarino!

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Where was thy judgement man
To extoll a virgin, Sanazarro tells me
Is neerer to deformity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: I saw her,
And curiously perus'd her, and I wonder
That she that did appeare to me, that know
What beauty is, not worthy the observing,
Should so transport you.

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: Troth my Lord I thought then.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Thought? Didst thou not affirme it?

SP.SPEAKER: Contarino.
SP.L: I confesse Sir
I did beleeve so then, but now I heare
My Lords opinion to the contrary,
I am of another faith: for 'tis not fit
That I should contradict him. I am dimme Sir,
But he's sharpe sighted.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: This is to my wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozi.
SP.L: We know not what to think of this, yet would not
Determine rashly of it. How doe you like
My Nephewes horsemanship?

SP.SPEAKER: Hippolito.
SP.L: In my judgement Sir
It is exact and rare.

SP.SPEAKER: Alphonso.
SP.L: And to my fancie
He did present great Alexander mounted
On his Bucephalus.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: You are right Courtiers,
And know it is your duty to cry up
All actions of a Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Doe not betray
Your selfe, you are safe, I have done my part.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: I thanke you,
Nor will I faile.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: What's your opinion Nephew
Of the horses?

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Two of them are in my judgement
The best I ever back'd. I meane the roane Sir,
And the browne bay: but for the chesnut colour'd,
Though he be full of mettall, hot, and fierie,
He treads weake in his pasternes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: So, come neerer;
This exercise hath put you into a sweat,
Take this and dry it: and now I command you
To tell me truly what's your censure of
Charomontes daughter Lidia.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: I am Sir
A novice in my judgement of a Lady,
But such as it is, your Grace shall heare it freely.
I would not speake in of her, and am sorie
If I keepe my selfe a friend to truth, I cannot
Report her as I would, so much I owe
Her reverend Father. But I'll give you Sir
As neere as I can her character in little.
She's of a goodly stature, and her limbs
Not disproportion'd; for her face it is
Farre from deformity, yet they flatter her
That style it excellent: her manners are
Simple and innocent: but her discourse
And wit deserve my pittie, more then praise.
At her best my Lord, she is a hansome picture,
And that said, all is spoken.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: I beleeve you
I ne're yet found you false.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Nor ever shall Sir.
Forgive me matchlesse Lidia I too much love
And jealous feare to lose thee, doe bompell me
Against my will, my reason, and my knowledge
To be a poore ditracter of that beauty,
Which fluent Ovid, if he liv'd againe,
Would want words to expresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Pray you make choyce of
The richest of our furniture for those horses,
And take my Nephew with you, we in this
Will follow his directions.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Could I finde now
The Princesse Fiorinda, and perswade her
To be silent in the suit, that I mov'd to her
All were secure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: In that my Lord t'll ayde you.

SP.SPEAKER: Coz.
SP.L: We wil be private, leave us. All my studies
And serious meditations ayme no further
Then this young mans good. He was my sisters son,
And she was such a sister when she liv'd
I could not prize too much, nor can I better
Make knowne how deere I hold her memory,
Then in my cherishing the onely issue
Which she hath left behind her Who's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: My faire charge, you are welcome to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: I have found it Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: All things goe well in Urbin.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: Your gracious care to me an Orphan, frees me
From all suspition, that my jealous feares can drive into my fancie.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: The next Summer
In our owne person, we will bring you thither,
And seat you in your owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: When you think fit Sir.
But in the mean time, with your Highnesse pardon,
I am a suitor to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Name it Madame,
With confidence to obtaine it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: That you would please
To lay a strict command on Charomonte,
To bring his daughter Lidia to the Court,
And pray you think Sir that 'tis not my purpose
To imploy her as a servant, but to use her
As a most wish'd companion.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Ha. Your reason?

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorin.
SP.L: The hopefull Prince your Nephew Sir hath given her
To me for such an abstract of perfection,
In all that can be wish'd for in a virgin,
As beauty, musique, ravishing discourse,
Quicknesse of apprehension, with choyce manners
And learning to, not usuall with women;
That I am much ambitious (though I shall
Appeare but as a foyle to set her off)
To be from her instructed, and suppli'd
In what I am defective.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Did my Nephew
Seriously deliver this?

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: I assure your Grace
With zeale, and vehemencie, and even when
With his best words he striv'd to set her forth
(Though the rare subject made him eloquent)
He would complaine, all he could say came short
Of her deservings.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Pray you have patience.
This was strangely caried. Ha! are we tristed with?
Dare they doe this? is Cozimos furie, that
Of late was terrible, growne contemptible?
Well; we will cleare our browes, and undermine
Their secret works, (though they have dig'd like Moles,)
And crush'em with the tempest of my wrath
When I appeare most calme. He is unfit
To command others, that knowes not to use it,
And with all rigour, yet my sterne lookes shall not
Discover my intents, for I will strike
When I begin to frowne. You are the Mistresse
Of that you did demand.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: I thank your Highnesse,
But speed in the performance of the grant
Doubles the favours Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: You shall possesse it sooner then you expect,
Onely be pleas'd to be ready when my Secretary
Waites upon you, to take the fresh ayre. My Nephew!
And my bosome friend so to cheat me, 'tis not faire!

SP.SPEAKER: San.
SP.L: Where should this Princesse be? nor in her lodgings,
Nor in the private walks, Her owne retreat
Which she so much frequented?

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: By my life
She's with the Duke. And I much more then feare
Her forwardnesse to prefer my suit, hath ruin'd
What with such care we built up.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Have you furnish'd
Those Coursers, as we will'd you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: There's no signe
Of anger in his lookes.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: They are compleat Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: 'Tis well. To your rest. Soft sleepes wayt on you Madame.
Tomorrow with the rising of the Sunne
Be ready to ride with us. They with more safety
Had trod on fork-tongu'd Adders, thē provok'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: I come not to be thank'd Sir for the speedy
Performance of my promise touching Lidia,
It is effected.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: We are undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: The Duke
No sooner heard me with my best of language
Describe her excellencies, as you taught me,
But he confirm'd it. You looke sad, as if
You wish'd it were undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: No gracious Madame,
I am your servant for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: Be you as carefull
For what I mov'd to you. Count Sanazarro,
Now I perceive you honour me, in vouchsafing
To weare so sleight a favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: 'Tis a grace
I am unworthy of.

SP.SPEAKER: Fiorinda.
SP.L: You merit more
In prizing so a trifle. Take this Diamond,
I'll second what I have begun. For know
Your valour hath so woone upon me, that
'Tis not to be resisted. I have said Sir,
And leave you to interpret it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: This to me
Is Wormewood. 'Tis apparant we are taken
In our owne nooze. What's to be done?

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: I know not.
And 'tis a punishment justly salne upon me
For leaving truth, a constant Mistresse, that
Ever protects her servants, to become
A slave to lyes, and falshood. What excuse
Can we make to the Duke? what mercy hope for,
Our packing being laid open?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: 'Tis not to
Be question'd, but his purpos'd journey is
To see faire Lidia.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: And to divert him
Impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: There's now no looking backward.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: And which way to goe on with safety not
To be imagin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: Give me leave. I have
An Embrion in my braine, which, I despaire not,
May be brought to forme and fashion, provided
You will be open breasted.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: 'Tis no time now
Our dangers being equall, to conceale
A thought from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: What power hold you o're Lidia?
Doe you think that with some hazard of her life
She would prevent your ruine?

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: I presume so.
If in the undertaking it, she stray not
From what becomes her innocence, and to that
'Tis farre from me to presse her, I my selfe
Will rather suffer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: 'Tis enough, this night
Write to her by your servant Calandrino
As I shall give directions, my man
Shall beare him company. See Sir to my wish
He does appeare, but much transform'd from what
He was when he came hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: I confesse
I am not very wise, and yet I finde
A foole, so he be parcell knave in Court,
May flourish and grow rich.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Calandrino.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: Peace.
I am in contemplation.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovanni.
SP.L: Doe not you know me?

SP.SPEAKER: Caland.
SP.L: I tell thee? no, on forfeit of my place,
I must not know my selfe, much lesse my Father,
But by Petition. That Petition lin'd too
With golden birds, that sing to the tune of Profit,
Or I am deafe.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: But you have your sense of feeling.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: Nay pray you forbeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandri.
SP.L: I have all that's requisite
To the making up of a Signior. My spruce ruffe,
My hooded cloake, long stockin, and pain'd hose,
My Case of tooth-picks, and my silver forke,
To convey an Olive neatly to my mouth,
And what is all in all, my pockets ring
A golden peale. O that the Pesants in the Country
(My quondam fellowes) but saw me as I am,
How they would admire and worship me!

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: As they shall,
For instantly you must thither.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandri.
SP.L: My grand Signior
Vouchsafe a bezolus manus, and a cringe
Of the last edition.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: You must ride post with Letters
This night to Lidia.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandr.
SP.L: And it please your Grace
Shall I use my Coach, or foot-cloath Mule?

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: You Whidgin,
You are to make all speed, think not of pompe.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: Follow for your instructions Sirra.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandr.
SP.L: I have one suit to you
My good Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: What is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Calandr.
SP.L: That you would give me
A subtill Court charme, to defend me from
Th infectious ayre of the Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: What's the reason?

SP.SPEAKER: Caland.
SP.L: Why, as this Court ayre taught me knavish wit,
By which I am growne rich, if that againe
Should turne me foole and honest; Vaine hopes farewell,
For I must die a beggar.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: Goe too Sirrha,
You'll be whip'd for this.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: Leave fooling, and attend us.

DIV2.TRAILER: The end of the third Act.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: DAughter I have observ'd since the Prince left us
(Whose absence I mourn with you, & the visit
Count Sanazarro gave us, you have nourish'd
Sad and retired thoughts, and parted with
That freedome, and alacrity of spirit
With which you us'd to cheere me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: For the Count, Sir,
All thought of him does with his person die;
But I confesse ingenuously I cannot
So soone forget the choyce, and chast delights
The curteous conversation of the Prince,
And without staine I hope, afforded me
When he made this house a Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: It is in us
To keepe it so without him. Want we know not,
And all we can complaine of (heaven be prais'd for)
Is too much plenty, & we will make use of
All lawfull pleasures. How now fellowes, when
Shall we have this lusty dance?

SP.SPEAKER: Caponi.
SP.L: In the after-noone Sir,
'Tis a device Iwis of my owne making,
And such a one, as shal make your Signiorship know
I have not beene your Butlar for nothing, but
I have crotchets in my head. We'll trip it titely,
And make my sad young Mistresse merry againe,
Or I'll forsware the Cellar.

SP.SPEAKER: Bernardo.
SP.L: If we had
Our fellow Calandrino here to dance
His part, we were perfect.

SP.SPEAKER: Petruchia.
SP.L: O, he was a rare fellow;
But I feare the Court hath spoil'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Caponi.
SP.L: When I was young
I could have cut a caper on a pinnacle,
But now I am old & wise, keepe your figure faire,
And follow but the sample I shall set you,
The Duke himselfe will send for us, and laugh at us,
And that were credit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: Who have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: Calandrino.
SP.L: I finde
VVhat was brawne in the Country, in the Court growes tender.
The bots on these joulting Jades, I am bruis'd to jelly.
A Coach for my mony! and that the Curtezans know well,
Their riding so, makes them last three yeares longer
Then such as are hacknei'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Calandrino, 'tis he.

SP.SPEAKER: Calan.
SP.L: Now to my postures. Let my hand have the honor
To convey a kisse from my lips to the cover of
Your foote deere Signior.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Fie, you stoope too low Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Calan.
SP.L: The hemme of your vestment Lady. Your Glove is for Princes,
Nay, I have con'd my distances.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: 'Tis most Courtly.

SP.SPEAKER: Caponi.
SP.L: Fellow Calandrino!

SP.SPEAKER: Caland.
SP.L: Signior de Caponi,
Grand Botelier of the Mansion.

SP.SPEAKER: Bernardo.
SP.L: How is't man?

SP.SPEAKER: Calan.
SP.L: Be not so rustique in your salutations,
Signior Bernardo, Master of the accounts.
Signior Petruchio, may you long continue
Your function in the chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Caponi.
SP.L: When shall we learne such gambolls in our villa?

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: Sure he's mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Carol.
SP.L: 'Tis not unlike, for most of such mushroomes are so.
What newes at Court?

SP.SPEAKER: Caland.
SP.L: Basto! they are mysteries,
And not to be reveal'd. With your favour Signior,
I am in private to conferre a while
With this Signiora. But I'll pawne my honour,
That neither my terse language, nor my habit
How e're it may convince, nor my new shrugs,
Shall render her enamour'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Take your pleasure
A little of these apish tricks may passe,
Too much is tedious.

SP.SPEAKER: Calandr.
SP.L: The Prince in this paper
Presents his service. Nay, it is not Courtly
To see the seale broke open. So I leave you.
Signiors of the Villa, I'll descend to be
Familiar with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Caponi.
SP.L: Have you forgot to dance?

SP.SPEAKER: Caland.
SP.L: No, I am better'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Petruch.
SP.L: Will you joyne with us?

SP.SPEAKER: Caland.
SP.L: As I like the project.
Let me warme my braines first with the richest Grape,
And then I am for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Caponi.
SP.L: We will want no wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lidia.
SP.L: That this comes onely from the best of Princes,
With a kinde of adoration does command me
To entertaine it, and the sweet contents
That are inscrib'd here by his hand, must be
Much more then musicall to me. All the service
Of my life at no part can deserve this favour.
O what a virgin longing I feele on me.
To unrip the seale, and reade it, yet to breake
What he hath fastned, rashly, may appeare
A sawcie rudenesse in me. I must doe it,
(Nor can I else learne his commands, or serve'em)
But with such reverence, as I would open
Some holy Writ, whose grave instructions beat downe
Rebellious sinnes, and teach my better part
How to mount upward. So, 'tis done, & I
With Eagles eyes wil curiously peruse it.

L.HI: Chast Lidia: the favours are so great
On me by you conferr'd, that to intreat
The least addition to 'em, in true sense
May argue me of blushlesse impudence.
But such are my extreames, if you denie
A farther grace, I must unpittied die.
Hast cuts off circumstance; as you are admir'd
for beauty, the report of it hath fir'd
The Duke my Vncle, and I feare you'll prove,
Not with a sacred, but unlawfull love.
If he see you, as you are, my hop'd-for light
Is chang'd into an everlasting night.
How to prevent it, if your goodnesse finde
You save two lives, and me you ever binde,

SP.L: The honourer of your vertues, Giovanni.
Were I more deafe then Adders, these sweet charmes
Would through my eares finde passage to my soule,
And soone inchant it: To save such a Prince
VVho would not perish? Vertue in him must suffer,
And piety be forgotten. The Dukes lust
Though it rag'd more then Tarquins, shall not reach me.
All quaint inventions of chast virgins ayde me!
My prayers are heard, I have't. The Duke ne're saw me,
Or if that faile, I am againe provided.
SP.STAGE: This spoke as if shee studied an evasion.
SP.L: But for the servants! They wil take what forme
I please to put upon them. Giovanni.
Be safe, thy servant Lidia assures it.
Let mountaines of afflictions fall on me,
Their waight is easie, so I set thee free.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazar.
SP.L: ARe you not tyr'd with travaile Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: No, no,
I am fresh and lustie.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: This day shall be ever
A holy day to me, that brings my Prince
Under my humble roofe.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: See Sir, my good Tutor
Sheds teares for joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Dry them up Charomonte,
And all forbeare the roome, while we exchange
Some private words together.

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: O my Lord,
How grosly have we overshot our selves!

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: In what Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Giovan.
SP.L: In forgetting to acquaint
My Guardian with our purpose; all that Lidia
Can doe, availes us nothing; if the Duke
Finde out the truth from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sanazarro.
SP.L: 'Tis now pass'd helpe,
And we must stand the hazard, hope the best Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: My loyalty doubted Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: 'Tis more. Thou hast
Abus'd our trust, and in a high degree
Committed treason.

SP.SPEAKER: Carolo.
SP.L: Treason? 'tis a word
My innocence understands not. VVere my breast
Transparent, and my thoughts to be discern'd,
Not one spot shall be found to taynt the candor
Of my alleageance. And I must be bold
To tell you Sir (for he that knowes no guilt
Can know no feare) 'tis tyrannie to o're charge
An honest man, and such till now I have liv'd,
And such my Lord I'll die.

SP.SPEAKER: Cozimo.
SP.L: Sir, doe not flatter
